character_intr_1: Lü Meng was a military general who served under the warlord Sun Quan. in a carefully calculated military operation, swiftly and stealthily capturing all the lands from Liu Bei's general Guan Yu. who was captured and executed after his defeat.
character_intr_2: Zhang Fei and Guan Yu, who were among the earliest to join Liu Bei, shared a brotherly relationship with their lord and accompanied him on most of his early exploits.
character_intr_3: Zhang Liao was a military general serving under the warlord Cao Cao in the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. One of the Five Elite Generals of his time, alongside Yu Jin, Zhang He, Yue Jin and Xu Huang.
character_intr_4: Zhao Yun was a military general who lived during the late Eastern Han dynasty and early Three Kingdoms period of China. in which he was lauded as a member of the Five Tiger Generals under Liu Bei.
character_intr_5: Lü Bu was an exceptionally mighty warrior, But he switched allegiances erratically and freely betrayed his allies, He was always suspicious of others and could not control his subordinates. All these factors ultimately led to his downfall.
character_intr_6: Gan Ning was a military general serving under the warlord Sun Quan. Originally a notorious pirate, Throughout his years of service under Sun Quan until his death, Gan Ning fought in numerous battles for his lord.
character_intr_7: Huang Zhong was one of the Five Tiger Generals under Liu Bei.He is best known for his victory at the Battle of Mount Dingjun in 219, in which his force routed that of an enemy general, Xiahou Yuan, who was killed in action during the raid.
character_intr_8: Ma Chao was the eldest son of Ma Teng, a prominent warlord in Liang Province. one of the Five Tiger Generals under Liu Bei.
character_intr_9: Xiahou Dun was a military general serving under the warlord Cao Cao . As one of Cao Cao's most trusted generals, Xiahou Dun aided the warlord in his campaigns against Lü Bu, Liu Bei, Sun Quan and others.
character_intr_10: Sun Ce  was the eldest child of Sun Jian, With the help of several people, such as Zhang Zhao and Zhou Yu, managed to lay down the foundation of the state of Eastern Wu. He was also referred to as the "Little Conqueror" in popular culture.
character_intr_11: Cao Cao laid the foundations for what was to become the state of Cao Wei and was posthumously honoured as "Emperor Wu of Wei". He has been praised as a brilliant ruler and military genius who treated his subordinates like his family.
character_intr_12: Zhou Yu was a military general and strategist serving under the warlord Eastern Wu. He is primarily known for his leading role in defeating the numerically superior forces of the northern warlord Cao Cao at the Battle of Red Cliffs.
character_intr_13: Lu Xun was a military general and statesman of the state of Eastern Wu. He served as the field commander of the Wu army in the Battle of Xiaoting against Liu Bei's forces and scored a decisive victory over the enemy.
character_intr_14: Sima Yi is best known for defending Wei from a series of invasions between 230 and 234 by Wei’s rival state, Shu. His success and subsequent rise to power as the regent of Wei paved the way for the establishment of the Jin dynasty.
character_intr_15: Zhuge Liang served as the Imperial Chancellor and regent of the state of Shu Han. He is recognised as the most accomplished strategist of his era, and has been compared to Sun Tzu, the author of The Art of War.
character_intr_16: Guo Jia was an adviser to the warlord Cao Cao. He aided Cao Cao greatly with his brilliance and foresight, and his strategies were instrumental to Cao Cao's triumphs over rival warlords such as Lü Bu and Yuan Shao.
character_intr_17: Yan Liang was a military general serving under the warlord Yuan Shao during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. He was slain by Guan Yu at the Battle of Boma.
character_intr_18: Wen Chou was a military general serving under the warlord Yuan Shao during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. His force was defeated by that of rival warlord Cao Cao in the Battle of Yan Ford and he was killed in the midst of battle.
character_intr_19: Pang De started his career under the warlord Ma Teng, He eventually came to serve Cao Cao. In 219, Pang De fought at the Battle of Fancheng. Pang De was captured in battle and eventually executed by Guan Yu when he refused to surrender.
character_intr_20: Zhang He was a military general serving under the warlord Cao Cao. One of the Five Elite Generals of his time, alongside Yu Jin, Yue Jin, Zhang Liao and Xu Huang.
character_intr_21: Zhou Tai was a military general serving under the warlord Sun Quan during the late Eastern Han dynasty and early Three Kingdoms period of China. He previously served under Sun Ce, Sun Quan's elder brother and predecessor.
character_intr_22: Wei Yan was a military general of the state of Shu Han. Between 228 and 234, he participated actively in the Northern Expeditions. After Zhuge Liang's death in 234, Wei Yan was killed by another Shu general, Ma Dai, for alleged treason.
character_intr_23: Zhang Ren was a military officer serving under the warlord Liu Zhang during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_24: Xiahou Yuan was a military general serving under the warlord Cao Cao in the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. in which he was slain by Liu Bei's general Huang Zhong during a surprise raid.
character_intr_25: Xu Huang was a military general serving under the warlord Cao Cao  One of the Five Elite Generals of his time, alongside Yu Jin, Zhang He, Yue Jin and Zhang Liao.
character_intr_26: Cheng Pu was a military general serving under the warlord Sun Quan during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. He previously served under Sun Quan's predecessors: Sun Jian and Sun Ce.
character_intr_27: Huang Gai was a military general who served under the warlord Sun Quan during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. He previously served under Sun Quan's predecessors – Sun Jian and Sun Ce.
character_intr_28: Ding Feng was a military general of the state of Eastern Wu during the Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_29: Cao Zhang was a prince of the state of Cao Wei. He served as a general under his father, having led his troops to significant victories against Wuhuan tribe incursions on the northern frontier.
character_intr_30: Lü Meng was a military general who served under the warlord Sun Quan. in a carefully calculated military operation, swiftly and stealthily capturing all the lands from Liu Bei's general Guan Yu. who was captured and executed after his defeat.
character_intr_31: Ling Tong was a military general serving under the warlord Sun Quan He started his service under Sun Quan when he was still a teenager and,  He fought in numerous battles for his lord.
character_intr_32: Wang Shuang was a military officer of the state of Cao Wei during the Three Kingdoms period of China. He was reassigned to the western front to fight against Wei's other rival state, Shu Han. He was killed in battle against Shu forces.
character_intr_33: Jiang Wei was a military general of the state of Shu. He continued Zhuge Liang's legacy of waging war against Wei by leading another 11 military campaigns.
character_intr_34: Sun Jian was a military general and warlord who lived during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. Sun Jian was also the father of Sun Quan, one of the central figures of the Three Kingdoms.
character_intr_35: Sima Shi was a military general and regent of Cao Wei. He assisted his father Sima Yi in overthrowing the emperor Cao Fang's regent Cao Shuang, allowing the Sima family to become paramount authority in the state.
character_intr_36: Sima Zhao was a military general, politician and regent of the state of Cao Wei. His military credit helped to set up the plot of overthrowing Wei by his son, Sima Yan, who usurped the Wei throne and proclaimed the Jin Dynasty.
character_intr_37: Zhuge Zhan was a military general and official of the state of Shu Han during the Three Kingdoms period of China. He was a son of Zhuge Liang, the first Imperial Chancellor of Shu.
character_intr_38: Lu Su was a military general and official serving under the warlord Sun Quan. Before the Battle of Red Cliffs, he was the first person to persuade Sun Quan to ally with Liu Bei against Cao Cao.
character_intr_39: Chen Gong was an adviser to the warlord Lü Bu in the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. He was executed along with Lü Bu after Cao Cao defeated Lü Bu at the Battle of Xiapi.
character_intr_40: Zhang Jue was the leader of the Yellow Turban Rebellion during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. He was said to be a follower of Taoism and a sorcerer.
character_intr_41: Zhong Hui was a military general of Cao Wei. He was already known for being insightful, intelligent and knowledgeable since he was young.
character_intr_42: Lu Kang was a military general of the state of Wu during the Three Kingdoms period of China. He was the second son of Lu Xun, the third Imperial Chancellor of Wu. Lu Kang was less involved in politics as he served mainly in the Wu military.
character_intr_43: Sun Quan was the founder of the state of Eastern Wu. He inherited control of the warlord regime established by his elder brother, Sun Ce, in 200. He declared formal independence and from 229 to 252 as the Emperor of Wu.
character_intr_44: Cao Ren was a military general serving under the warlord Cao Cao. He played a significant part in assisting Cao Cao in the civil wars leading to the end of the Han dynasty.
character_intr_45: Guan Ping was a military general serving under the warlord Liu Bei during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_46: Yan Yan was a general who initially serves under Liu Zhang before switching allegiance to Liu Bei later.
character_intr_47: Chen Dao was a military general of the state of Shu Han in the Three Kingdoms period of China. He previously served under the warlord Liu Bei, the founding emperor of Shu Han, in the late Eastern Han dynasty.
character_intr_48: Wen Ping was a military general who lived during the late Eastern Han dynasty and Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_49: Wang Ping was a military general of the state of Shu Han. During his service in Shu, he steadily rose through the ranks to become a senior general. The highest position he reached was Senior General Who Guards the North .
character_intr_50: Cao Xiu was a military general of the state of Cao Wei. A distant younger relative of the warlord Cao Cao, Cao Xiu started his career in the late Eastern Han dynasty as a military officer under Cao Cao.
character_intr_51: Zhou Cang was a strong warrior with a dark face and a wiry beard, He is appointed as Guan Yu's weapon bearer. He commits suicide after learning that Guan Yu and Guan Ping have been captured and executed by Sun Quan's forces.
character_intr_52: Hua Xiong was a military general serving under the warlord Dong Zhuo during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_53: Dong Zhuo was a military general and warlord who lived in the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. Dong Zhuo rose to power in the Han imperial court and ruled the nation with tyranny and cruelty for a brief period of time.
character_intr_54: Gao Shun was a military officer serving the warlord Lü Bu during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. Although he only had 700 men under his command, his unit was nicknamed as the "camp crusher" for its destructive charges.
character_intr_55: Yuan Shao was a warlord who lived in the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. One of the most powerful warlords of his time, In 200, he launched a campaign against his rival Cao Cao but was defeated at the Battle of Guandu.
character_intr_56: Xu Sheng was a military general serving under the warlord Sun Quan in the late Eastern Han dynasty and early Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_57: Ma Dai was a military general of the state of Shu Han during the Three Kingdoms period of China. He participated in the fifth Northern Expedition led by Shu's chancellor Zhuge Liang to attack the Shu's rival state Cao Wei.
character_intr_58: Cao Hong was a military general of the state of Cao Wei during the Three Kingdoms period of China. He started his career in the late Eastern Han dynasty under the warlord Cao Cao, who was also an older second cousin of his.
character_intr_59: Yu Jin was a military general serving under the warlord Cao Cao in the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. One of the Five Elite Generals of his time, alongside Zhang He, Yue Jin, Zhang Liao and Xu Huang.
character_intr_60: Sun Huan was a military general of the state of Eastern Wu during the Three Kingdoms period. He was a distant relative of Sun Quan, the founding emperor of Wu.
character_intr_61: Zhurong is the wife of the Nanman chieftain Meng Huo, who rules the lands in the Nanzhong region of the state of Shu Han during the Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_62: Meng Huo was a local leader representing the gentries of the Nanzhong region during the Three Kingdoms period of China. Zhuge Liang captured and released the local leader seven times until he finally swore allegiance to Shu Han.
character_intr_63: King Wutugu served under Meng Huo and was king of the land of Wu Ge. He wore scale armor mixed with oil. This helped make the Nanman armored troops and made sure weapons could not penetrate the armor.
character_intr_64: Cao Zhen was a military general of the state of Cao Wei during the Three Kingdoms period of China. He was an adopted son of Cao Cao, a warlord who rose to power in the late Eastern Han dynasty and laid the foundation for Wei.
character_intr_65: Guo Huai was a military general of the state of Cao Wei. He started his career towards the end of the Eastern Han dynasty under the warlord Cao Cao as a subordinate of Cao Cao's generals Xiahou Yuan and Zhang He.
character_intr_66: Fu Qian was a military general of the state of Shu Han in the Three Kingdoms period of China. He was the son of Fu Rong.
character_intr_67: Zhuge Shang was a military officer of the state of Shu Han in the Three Kingdoms period of China. He was the eldest son of the Shu general Zhuge Zhan and a grandson of Zhuge Liang, the first Chancellor of Shu.
character_intr_68: Zhang Bao was a Yellow Turban rebel leader, Zhang Jue's brother.
character_intr_69: Shen Pei was an official serving under the warlord Yuan Shao during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China. Xun Yu, an official serving under Yuan Shao's rival Cao Cao, once said that Shen Pei was "strong of will but without tact".
character_intr_70: Ju Shou was an adviser serving under the warlord Yuan Shao during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_71: Man Chong was a military general of the state of Cao Wei. He is best known for defending the city of Hefei from a series of invasions by Wei's rival state, Eastern Wu, between 230 and 235.
character_intr_72: Zhu Ran was a military general of the state of Eastern Wu during the Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_73: Kan Ze was an official of the state of Eastern Wu during the Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_74: Li Ru was an official serving under the warlord Dong Zhuo during the Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_75: a Yellow Turban rebel leader killed by Zhang Fei.
character_intr_76: a Yellow Turban leader killed by Guan Yu.
character_intr_77: a former Yellow Turban rebel who established a bandit stronghold together with Zhou Cang. Pei Yuanshao was killed by Zhao Yun when he attempted to steal his horse.
character_intr_78: a Yellow Turban rebel leader, Zhang Jue's brother.
character_intr_80: Liao Hua was a military general of the state of Shu Han during the Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_82: Hu Zhen was a military officer serving under the warlord Dong Zhuo during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_83: Xu Rong was a military officer serving under the warlord Dong Zhuo during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.

character_intr_85: Guo Si was a military officer serving under the warlord Dong Zhuo during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.

character_intr_98: Niu Jin was a military general serving under the warlord Cao Cao during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_99: Jin Xuan was an official and minor warlord who lived during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_101: Chen Ying, Zhao Fan's subordinate. He was killed by Zhao Yun.
character_intr_102: Liu Xian, the son of Liu Du, the Administrator of Lingling Commandery. He joined Xing Daorong in the attempt to ambush Liu Bei's forces but ended up getting captured by Zhang Fei.
character_intr_103: Xing Daorong, a general serving under Liu Du. When Liu Bei invaded Lingling Commandery, Xing duelled with Liu Bei's generals Zhang Fei and Zhao Yun but was defeated and captured by them.
character_intr_104: Han Hao was a military officer serving under the warlord Cao Cao during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_105: Han Xuan  was an official and minor warlord who lived during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_106: Liu Bei's takeover of Yi Province was a military campaign by the warlord Liu Bei in taking control of Yi Province from the provincial governor, Liu Zhang.
character_intr_107: Liu Bei's takeover of Yi Province was a military campaign by the warlord Liu Bei in taking control of Yi Province from the provincial governor, Liu Zhang.

character_intr_112: Huo Jun was a military general serving under the warlord Liu Bei in the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_113: Zhang Yi was a military general serving under the warlord Liu Bei in the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_114: Xiahou De was a military general serving under the warlord Cao Cao in the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_115: Xiahou Shang was a military general serving under the warlord Cao Cao in the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_116: a military officer serving under the warlord Sun Quan during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.

character_intr_120: Tan Xiong, Sun Huan's subordinate. He was killed by Guan Xing at the Battle of Xiaoting.
character_intr_121: a military officer serving under the warlord Sun Quan during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_122: a subordinate of Meng Huo. He was executed by Meng Huo along with Dongtuna.
character_intr_123: Dongtuna, a subordinate of Meng Huo. He joined Ahuinan and Jinhuan Sanjie in defending Nanman territory from the Shu invasion.
character_intr_128: a Wei general who followed Xiahou Mao to deal with the Shu invasion led by Zhuge Liang. He was killed by Zhao Yun, who also killed his four sons.
character_intr_129: Xiahou Mao was a military general of the state of Cao Wei during the Three Kingdoms period of China. He married Princess Qinghe, one of Cao Cao's daughters, and held the title of a marquis.
character_intr_130: Sun Li was an official and military general of the state of Cao Wei during the Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_131: an official and military general of the state of Cao Wei during the Three Kingdoms period of China.

character_intr_139: Sun Hao was the fourth and last emperor of the state of Eastern Wu during the Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_140: an official and military general of the state of Dong Zhuo during the Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_141: an official and military general of the state of Dong Yuan Shao the Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_142: an official and military general of the state of Dong Yuan Shao the Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_143: an adviser to the warlord Yuan Shao.
character_intr_144: an adviser to Jin Xuan, the Administrator of Wuling Commandery. He urged his lord to surrender when Zhang Fei attacked Wuling, but Jin Xuan ignored him. Gong Zhi then killed Jin Xuan and surrendered to Zhang Fei.
character_intr_145: Zhao Fan was a government official and minor warlord who lived during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_146: Liu Du was a government official and minor warlord who lived during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
character_intr_147: an official and military general of the state of Shu Han during the Three Kingdoms period of China.
character_intr_148: King Duosi, the lord of Tulong Cave and an ally of Meng Huo. He assisted Meng Huo in countering the Shu army. The poisonous springs and mist outside Tulong Cave posed a big problem to Zhuge Liang.
character_intr_149: King Mulu , the lord of Bana Cave and an ally of Meng Huo. He possessed magical powers and could change the weather and control wild beasts and direct them into battle.
character_intr_150: an adviser to the warlord Yuan Shao.
character_intr_151: an official and minor warlord who lived during the late Eastern Han dynasty of China.
